content.title: GLOBAL ENERGY INVESTMENT LANDSCAPE
content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2

content.text: This lesson provides an overview of global investment trends in the energy sector, highlighting the growth of renewable energy technologies such as solar, wind, and energy storage. It examines how global investment flows have evolved in recent years, emphasizing the increasing role of clean energy in the global energy mix. Additionally, the lesson discusses regional disparities in investment, particularly between developed and developing countries, and the urgent need for more capital to meet global climate goals. Learners will gain insights into the key drivers and challenges influencing energy investments worldwide

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: disparities in energy investments
concepts.body: Disparities in energy investments refer to the unequal distribution of financial resources and funding across different regions, communities, or sectors for energy projects, leading to imbalances in access to energy services and infrastructure.

concepts.title: energy transition triple penalty for developing countries
concepts.body: The energy transition triple penalty for developing countries refers to the challenges these nations face in shifting to sustainable energy sources, which include higher costs for renewable technologies, the need for significant infrastructure investment, and the potential loss of economic stability due to reliance on fossil fuels during the transition.

concepts.title: new collective quantified goal (ncqg)
concepts.body: A New Collective Quantified Goal (NCQG) is a specific, measurable target set by a group of countries or organizations to collectively address global challenges, such as climate change, by tracking progress and ensuring accountability.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Investments In Sustainable Energy

content.text: The global energy landscape is undergoing a transformation, driven primarily by the transition of energy systems in industrialized economies such as the United States, the EU, and China, rather than solely by efforts to close the energy access gap. In 2023, global energy investment was USD 2.8 trillion and is expected to surpass USD 3 trillion in 2024, with USD 2 trillion going to clean energy technologies and infrastructure. The global energy landscape is undergoing a transformation, driven by the urgent need to ensure sustainable, secure, and affordable energy access as well as to modern energy systems. In 2023, global energy investment was USD 2.8 trillion and is expected to surpass USD 3 trillion in 2024, with USD 2 trillion going to clean energy technologies. Global investments in energy transition technologies increased by 19% compared with 2021 and nearly 70% compared with 2019, pre-COVID-19 pandemic.

However, the current level of investment, while record-breaking, falls short of what is needed to achieve net-zero emissions by mid-century. Annual investments in energy transition technologies need to average $4.8 trillion from 2024 to 2030 to align with a Paris Agreement-compliant trajectory, indicating a significant gap that needs to be addressed. At COP29 in 2024, leaders agreed to mobilize $300 billion of climate finance target for 2025 and beyond, building on the previous $100 billion per year commitment.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Geographical Disparities in Energy Investments

content.text: Developing countries are in dire need of increased external investment in renewable energy to meet their SDGs and to transition to a cleaner energy future requiring about $1.7 trillion each year in renewable and clean energy investments to cover the necessities such as solar PVs, wind, power grids and storage. In 2024, Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) outside China account for only around 15% of global clean energy investment. more than half of the global population, predominantly residing in developing and emerging economies, received only 15% of global energy investments. Sub-Saharan Africa, for instance, received only 2% of the amount invested globally between 2000 and 2024 with most investments going to South Africa, Kenya, Uganda and Zambia. In 2021, investment per capita in Europe was 41 times that in Sub-Saharan Africa and 57 times more in North America. The investment gap in renewable energy is also reflected in disparities of investment per capita across different regions. Clean energy investments are rising globally, but most of the growth is concentrated in a few countries and regions.

China leads East Asia and Pacific investment, which accounts for two-thirds of global investment in 2022. China is on track to meet its 14th Five-Year Plan targets thanks to tax exemptions and other policies that have spurred solar and wind investment. Solar PV investment in Viet Nam grew 219% per year between 2013 and 2020, driven by feed-in tariffs. North America excluding Mexico attracted the second-largest share of investment in 2022, driven by the US production tax credit, followed by Europe, where net-zero commitments and extensive fossil fuel phaseout policies are driving renewables growth. In the United States, the energy-related provisions of the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, are expected to represent almost $870 billions of targeted support through 2031 in the form of tax credits, grants and loans, and investments in clean electricity, vehicle electrification, energy efficiency, carbon capture and storage and low-carbon hydrogen. The European Commission's Green Deal Industrial Plan for the Net-Zero Age provides investment aid and tax breaks for net-zero product development, manufacturing, production, and installation in renewables and hydrogen sectors. The plan seeks EUR 225 billion in loans from the Recovery and Resilience Facility and EUR 20 billion in grants.
On the other hand, 120 developing and emerging economies receive little investment.

Clean energy investments in these countries flow predominantly to Brazil, Chile, and India. In 2022, only 15% of global renewables investments went to more than 50% of the world's population, mostly in developing and emerging countries. Additionally, renewable energy investments in these regions have been declining (from 27% of the total investments in 2017 to 15% in 2022). Average annual investments have fallen 36% since 2018. Between 2013 and 2020, 0.84% of renewable energy investments went to “least developed” countries, according to the IPCC. In East Asia and the Pacific, investment per capita rose 51% from USD 70/person in 2015 to USD 105/person in 2021. China saw the biggest increase, while Japan dropped 45%. Except for these two countries, the region increased more than 6-fold, led by Viet Nam and the Republic of Korea. Investment per capita in South Asia fell 6% between 2015 and 2021, but India saw a 34% increase in the same period. Investment per capita fell 61% from USD 12/person in 2015 to USD 5/person in 2021, excluding India. The largest and fastest-growing gap is between Sub-Saharan Africa and North America (excluding Mexico) and Europe. North America (excluding Mexico) and Europe invested 23 times more in renewable energy per capita than Sub-Saharan Africa in 2015. In 2021, Europe invested 41 times more per capita than Sub-Saharan Africa (which fell to USD 3 from USD 6 in 2015), and North America 57 times more

Off-grid renewables investment is mostly in Sub-Saharan Africa. In 2010-2021, the region attracted USD 2.2 billion—more than 70% of global off-grid investments. It has one of the lowest electrification rates in the world, with 568 million people lacking access to electricity in 2020 (IEA, IRENA et al. 2022). East Africa, home to three of the top five off-grid investment recipients (Kenya, Tanzania, and Rwanda), received 43% of the total. Pay-as-you-go (PAYGO) business models leveraged local mobile money ecosystems to attract investment to these destinations. In 2010-2021, 78% of off-grid renewables commitments (USD 2.4 billion) were PAYG-funded, with East Africa accounting for USD 917 million. Southeast Asian off-grid renewable energy investments fell 98% during the COVID-19 pandemic, making key markets more vulnerable. While most countries in the region have high or near-universal electricity access, parts of Myanmar and Cambodia (26% and 15%, respectively in 2020) still lack electricity (World Bank, 2022). The region attracted USD 137 million in off-grid renewable energy investments in 2018–2019, led by Myanmar, but in 2020–2021, investments dropped to USD 3 million due to the COVID-19 pandemic and political developments. However, there is a strong potential for the development clean energy sectors in this region. By 2030, Southeast Asia's low-carbon mobility and clean energy sectors could represent a revenue opportunity of $90 billion to $100 billion. The region is already in a strong position to meet the growing demand for components in these areas. It currently produces 9%–10% of the world's solar photovoltaic (PV) cells and modules, about half of global nickel production, and 6%–10% of all electric two-wheelers.[1]

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Triple Penalty of Energy Transition in Developing Country

content.text: Developing countries encounter a "triple penalty" in their energy transition efforts: higher electricity costs, limited access to clean energy projects, higher cost of funding for energy projects and risk to be stuck in fossil fuel/carbon lock-in. This multifaceted challenge hampers economic growth and exacerbates energy poverty.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 3 | A
content.title: A. Higher Costs for Electricity

content.text: An increase in fossil fuel prices significantly impacts households worldwide. Between February and September 2022, prices for coal and coal products surged by up to 235%, crude oil and petroleum products by up to 80%, and natural gas by up to 159%. These hikes in energy prices directly translate to increased household energy costs globally, straining budgets significantly. Total per capita household energy costs increased by a range of 62.6% to 112.9% globally, leading to a 2.7–4.8% rise in household expenditure. The distribution of these costs varies significantly across regions, with Central Asian households experiencing the largest direct increases in energy costs in Tajikistan, where direct energy costs soared by more than 176%. In Moldova energy price increase during 2022-2024 with an estimated 240% of natural gas price increase, and 75-100% increase for the price of electricity.

Conversely, Latin American households were among the least directly affected, with increases around 51.5%. Additionally subsidies play a crucial role, for example in Venezuela energy prices are heavily subsidized. In contrast, the Caribbean region generally experiences higher energy costs. include relevant examples, and provide a link to reliable data on energy costs to support the analysis.

A study focusing on electrifying all households in 40 Sub-Saharan African countries by 2030 highlighted several key aspects. The cost of electrifying these areas varies significantly depending on the level of service (Tier 2 to 4) with higher tiers necessitating greater capital. For instance, achieving Tier 3 levels of electrification results in average costs per person per day of USD16 cents, and for Tier 4, it escalates to USD40 cents per person per day. This presents a substantial challenge, particularly considering that 389 million people in these regions live below the poverty line.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 3 | B
content.title: B. Limited Access to Clean Energy Projects

content.text: Limited access to clean energy remains a significant challenge worldwide, impeding progress towards SDG 7, which aims for universal access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern energy by 2030. As of the latest reports, approximately 733 million people globally do not have access to electricity, and a staggering 2.4 billion people continue to rely on fuels that are harmful to health and the environment for cooking . The energy access landscape varies significantly across regions in developing countries. In Sub-Saharan Africa, where progress has been especially slow, the number of people without access to electricity has increased, reaching 600 million in 2022, nearly returning to historic highs.

This setback contrasts with significant advancements in Asia, where almost 1 billion people have gained access to electricity since 2010, largely due to ambitious government policies and the facilitation of financing. For instance, countries like India, Indonesia, and Bangladesh have managed to extend access to more than 99% of their populations. Despite these efforts, the current pace of progress suggests that by 2030, approximately 670 million people will remain without electricity, with the majority (85%) located in Sub-Saharan Africa. To bridge this gap, an estimated $30 billion per year is needed for generation, electricity networks, and decentralized solutions. The global scenario regarding access to clean energy reveals significant challenges and disparities across regions.

As of 2023, approximately 675 million people worldwide lack access to electricity, with a significant majority (567 million) residing in Sub-Saharan Africa, representing over 80% of the global population without electricity access. Additionally, 2.3 billion people still rely on harmful cooking fuels, predominantly located in Sub-Saharan Africa and Asia. These numbers suggest a substantial gap in achieving SDG 7 which aims for universal access to affordable, reliable, sustainable, and modern energy by 2030. Progress towards increasing access to electricity has been slow, with the share of the global population having access to electricity only increasing from 78% in 2000 to 91% in 2021. Despite significant gains in some regions, such as South Asia, where rapid development in the electricity sector over the last decade has greatly improved access, Sub-Saharan Africa remains notably behind. Analysis of nighttime lights and populated areas provides a stark illustration of the disparities in electricity access, showing that in regions like Sub-Saharan Africa, nighttime lights - indicative of electricity usage - are primarily concentrated in urban areas, leaving densely populated rural areas without adequate access .

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 2 | Part 3 | C
content.title: C. Dependence on Fossil Fuels

content.text: Fossil fuels continue to play a dominant role in the global energy mix and electricity generation, especially in developing countries. Approximately four-fifths of global primary energy comes from coal, oil, and gas, indicating a substantial reliance on fossil fuels. This reliance varies across regions, with some areas more dependent on specific types of fossil fuels for electricity production than others. For example, coal and gas are major sources of electricity globally, with oil contributing a smaller share. vh The financial aspect of fossil fuel consumption is also significant. In 2022, global fossil fuel subsidies reached $7 trillion, or 7.1 percent of GDP. These subsidies are not only due to undercharging for supply costs but also for not accounting for the environmental and health costs associated with fossil fuel consumption. The majority of these subsidies arise from undercharging for the costs of global warming and local air pollution .

Despite international climate agreements and growing awareness of the need for clean energy, the Production Gap Report 2023 highlights a concerning trend: governments plan to produce around 110% more fossil fuels by 2030 than would be consistent with limiting global warming to 1.5°C, and 69% more than would be consistent with a 2°C limit. This underscores a significant challenge in aligning national fossil fuel production plans with global climate targets .

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Investment in clean energy technologies is growing but remains insufficient to meet global climate targets and Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) outside China account for only around 15% of global clean energy investment.

Significant investment disparities exist in the global energy transition, with developing countries receiving only 15% of global renewable energy investments despite hosting over half of the world's population,
Regional disparities in energy transition investments highlight the need for equitable financing mechanisms.
